title: Saudi Arabia and the World Economic Forum Launch the 'Beyond Tourism' Initiative, Supporting Saudia & flynas's route expansion and a US $3.6 billion hospitality investment programme - Travel And Tour World
text:
Saudi Arabia and the World Economic Forum have launched the ‘Beyond Tourism’ initiative, marking a transformative shift in the global tourism landscape. This ambitious program, designed to promote sustainability, inclusion, and resilience, aims to reshape not only Saudi Arabia’s tourism sector but also the future of global travel. As part of this forward-thinking initiative, Saudi Arabia is simultaneously expanding its airline routes with carriers like Saudia and flynas, which are increasing their international and domestic connectivity. In addition, a significant US $3.6 billion hospitality investment is set to enhance the Kingdom’s hotel and resort offerings, aligning with the country’s Vision 2030. With these developments, Saudi Arabia is positioning itself as a global leader in sustainable tourism, offering travelers new, diverse, and responsible travel experiences while contributing to the growth of the airline and hospitality industries. This new era in Saudi tourism is poised to provide travelers with more accessible, sustainable, and enriching experiences.
Saudi Arabia and the World Economic Forum ‘Beyond Tourism’ Initiative Launches in the Hotel Market with Partnerships with Saudia & flynas and a US $3.6 Billion Investment in Hospitality Advertisement Saudi Arabia has long been a cultural and religious center of the world but recently has been transforming the tourism sector which has been bringing the attention of the world. ‘Beyond Tourism’ initiative has been in partnership with the World Economic Forum and has been a testament to the innovative potential of the Saudi tourism sector. ‘Beyond Tourism’ aims to be a robust framework to define and influence the future of tourism in Saudi Arabia and positively impact global tourism to become more sustainable.
Saudi Arabia has been pouring investments in the airline and hospitality industries and transformation has been taking place aligned with the 2030 vision framework which places tourism at the center of the economy. This article aims to highlight the exciting new changes taking place in the Saudi hospitality and airline industry and how these changes bridge the gaps and serve the new and ever-changing needs of global travelers.
The Launch of the ‘Beyond Tourism’ Initiative: Saudi Arabia and WSP
The Beyond Tourism initiative is much more than a coordination engagement of Saudi Arabia and the World Economic Forum. It represents a comprehensive desire and initiative to remodel the global tourism industry to become more sustainable, inclusive, and resilient. This initiative intends to make sure tourism provides economic returns as Saudi Arabia seeks to empower communities, protect ecosystems, and preserve cultural heritage. Its initiative patterns as principles tourism as sustainable tourism is possible by aligning market opportunities with local assets, advocating for local cultural heritage, and eco- rejuvenating local natural heritage. Advertisement This means the traveller experience is a more enriched and responsible one. The intent is to provide the experience of a heritage site with the site where the cultural heritage and local communities engage with the tourists. Saudi Arabia intends to provide a more sustainable and cultured experience on the shores of the Red Sea and desert as well as around the historical sites of the Kingdom.
Saudia and flynas’s Expanding Route Networks: New Connections for Global Travelers
Saudi Arabia’s flagship carrier, Saudia, moving forward to expanding world tourism, is expanding their network internationally. In 2025, Saudia is planned to open new destinations in Europe, Asia, and the Middle East. The East to West strategic expansion helps in connecting the world to Saudi Arabia and to the Kingdom’s newly opened destinations for tourism.
The number of flights to Riyadh, Jeddah and Dammam have been increased in both frequency and passenger capacity. Saudia is now accommodating more customers as the demand continues to increase. Saudia allows for direct flights to the major cities of London, New York, and Paris. For customers, this creates greater possibilities in their travels asmore modernization to the fleets will provide higher levels of service.
Moreover, flynas, the low-cost airline in Saudi Arabia, is concentrating on expanding its capacity to accommodate the demand brought on by the tourism boom. Apart from flynas’s low-cost fares and cheap pricing, the airline added new routes to flynas’s ever expanding destinations in the Middle East, Europe, and Asia, and serves budget travelers. The flynas focus is on the demand of the market in the Middle East and holds the market on cheap and affordable airline services. This makes Saudi Arabia a highly attractive tourism destination.
Hospitality Growth: US $3.6 Billion Investment in Hotels and Resorts
Saudi Arabia’s hospitality sector is focused on the most unprecedented growth, especially when it comes to mid scale and luxury accommodations. The US $3.6 billion hospitality investment programme issued by Al-Balad Development Company, and a part of Saudi Arabia’s Public Investment Fund (PIF), is amongst the kingdom’s largest investments, and has received a lot of attention. This will allow the addition of thousands of new bedrooms, and the building of new hotels, new resorts, and new service apartments in the most primary tourism destinations of Saudi Arabia.
New hotels from global chains like Marriott, Hilton, and Accor are set to reshape the Saudi luxury tourism scene. New developments include five-star resorts on the coast and heritage hotels in Al-Ula. These are positioned to provide high-end and authentic four to five-star experiences.
Improvements are not only being made to the high-end tourism offerings, hotels and developments for the mid-range and budget to spread the tourism demand more evenly. This is to increase the attractiveness of the country to the lower spending tourists. This lag on the lower end of the tourism spectrum is now in the process of being evened out.
Flight Details: Getting to Saudi Arabia
Tracking down flight options to Saudi Arabia has become exponentially simpler, given the number of international airlines expanding their network and the growing number of flights available to the country. Saudia, the country’s national airline, provides direct flights to Saudi Arabia and additional cities around the globe. Come 2025, the airline will host flights to Riyadh, Jeddah, and Dammam from cities including New York, London, Paris, and Dubai, amplifying the host of direct flight options available to customers. Their growing network of destinations has made it possible for Saudi Arabia to be more interconnected to the international travel network.
Flynas has also expanded the number of routes available to Saudi Arabia, especially from more regional Middle Eastern, Asian, and European countries. Their lower cost options for travel help serve customers while also enhancing the travel network for customers and limited travel budget.
Travelers in Saudi Arabia will also benefit the country’s robust domestic flights, with the coverage ensured by regular flights to key cities of Riyadh, Jeddah, Dammam, and Medina. The newer regional airports across the kingdom also focus on offering their customers enhanced, modern terminals and additional amenities.
What Tourists Need to Know: Travel Tips for Visiting Saudi Arabia
As Saudi Arabia continues to attract more tourists from around the world, travelers should understand the unique customs and practical considerations of the country. Below are some suggestions to enhance the experience of your visit: Visa Requirements : Saudi Arabia has recently implemented an e-visa system for travelers from select countries. E-visas are valid for tourism purposes and the application process is straightforward. Remember to review the e-visa policies that pertain to your country before making your travel arrangements. Cultural Etiquette : As a conservative society, Saudi Arabia has specific traditions that should be respected. While in public, all people should ensure they are covered adequately. Women should wear an abaya (loose-covering robe), although the guidelines for women visiting from abroad are more lenient. Public shorts for men are forbidden, especially in places of worship. Language : The official language of Saudi Arabia is Arabic, and it is common to hear it in all public interactions. Nevertheless, in major cities and tourist areas, English is spoken, especially by service providers. Familiarizing yourself with some basic Arabic phrases will help improve your experience. Local Cuisine : Saudi Arabian food is extensive and complex, with dishes like kabsa (a spiced rice dish), shawarma, and various grilled meats. Traditional Saudi Arabian desserts such as kunafa and baklava are also worth trying. Weather Considerations : Saudi Arabian predominantly desert climate consists of very hot summers and mild winters. To avoid the severe summer temperatures, it is recommended to travel during the cooler months, from October to March. Respect for Religion : Saudi Arabia is home to Mecca and Medina, two of the most holy cities in Islam. During the Hajj pilgrimage season, special attention is required regarding the religious customs in these cities. As such, non-Muslims are not permitted to enter the holy cities of Mecca and Medina, although they do host a number of other cultural and historical sites.
The Future of Saudi Tourism: A Glimpse of What’s to Come
The future of Saudi Arabia’s tourism sector appears promising. An increasing number of global airlines are adding routes to Saudi Arabia, and the government is welcoming global hotel brands. Investing in infrastructure including the ‘Beyond Saudi Tourism’ initiative to expand the tourism sector presents the Kingdom as a desirable tourist destination.
From understanding the historical background of the cities of Riyadh and Al-Ula to appreciating the beauty of the Red Sea, and the active lifestyle in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia has wide-ranging attractions. Every tourist may find something interesting to him, whether he is a history lover, an adventure traveler, a luxury seeker, or a person who looks for a destination to experience the rich heritage of Saudi Arabia.
Saudi Arabia and the World Economic Forum have launched the ‘Beyond Tourism’ initiative, driving a transformative shift in global tourism with a focus on sustainability and inclusion. This move, alongside expanding airline routes and a US $3.6 billion hospitality investment, positions Saudi Arabia as a key player in the future of travel.
Saudi Arabia’s Tourism’s Future
The increase in the number of tourist visits to Saudi Arabia is not the ultimate goal for the country’s comprehensive tourist plan. Saudi Arabia aims to build a tourism network that is sustainable, inclusive, resilient, and benefits the local population and the visitors. One of the major pillars for the achievement of this goal is the ‘Beyond Tourism’ plan, which aims to allow conscious and meaningful tourism visits to the country’s rich historical sites, cultural diversity, and natural beauty.
As the country is developing, its airline industry and the tourism and hospitality business will be key components of the growth of the country and will help improve the tourist experience. Saudi Arabia is becoming increasingly customer-friendly and will be an appealing tourist destination, offering travel experiences that are diverse, rich, and authentic, especially with the increase of flight routes, hotels, and the drive for sustainable tourism.
Regardless of your travel intentions, be it for leisure or cultural appreciation, you will be received by Saudi Arabia’s hospitality industry with no limitations. Initiatives aimed at ‘Beyond Tourism’ are at last the commencement of an invigorating phase pertaining to worldwide tourism. Advertisement
